newsitem.title: ECUADOR: Ecuador minister accuses Maxus of cost over-runs.
newsitem.headline: Ecuador minister accuses Maxus of cost over-runs.

text.p: Ecuador's Energy and Mines Minister Alfredo Adum Thursday accused Argentine-owned oil firm Maxus Energy Corp of cost over-runs and spoke of a possible "malicious attitude" of overpricing.
"Maxus comes along, carries out an investment project for $300 million in a year. It turns out it wasn't $300 million, it had become $700 million," Adum told local television.
"People say there was a malicious attitude of overpricing things ... all the equipment overpriced, on all the products, on all the constructions."
Adum added: "They began to extract oil and they took all the oil themselves and it was not enough to cover the costs of the goods they had constructed."
According to Adum, under Maxus's present oil contracts with the Ecuadoran government, the firm does not have to share its output with the state if its costs are high.

The government announced late Tuesday that it was banning the Dallas-based Maxus from continuing its operations in Ecuador until it reaches a joint-venture deal to share output with state-owned Petroecuador.
The owners of Maxus, Argentina's YPF SA, Wednesday said the Ecuadoran government had requested it to renegotiate its contracts. But it said its operations in Ecuador were functioning normally.
